publicationStmt.publisher: John Marston, 1575?-1634 (1576-1634) VVhat Yov VVill. By Iohn Marston London Imprinted ... by G. Eld. for Thomas Thorppe 1607

sourceDesc.p: STC17487 (1607), LION version, checked against page images from this version in EEBO

Play details
What you will. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1607. Date first performed: 1601.

encodingDesc.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Doricus Phylomuse/Phylus Atticus Quadratus Iacocomo Andrea/Adrean Randolfo Francisco Lauerdure Bydett Lampatho Doria Simplicus Faber Albano Doite Trip All Battus Pedante/SchoolMaster Celia Nous/Noose Slip Nathaniell Holofernes Pippo
Lyzabetta Lucea Duke Pan. Meletza

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Before the Music sounds for the Act: Enter Atticus, Doricus and Phylomuse they sit a good while on the Stage before the Candles are lighted, talking together, and on sudden Doricus speaks.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O fie some lights, sirs fie, let there be no deeds of darkness done among us. I so, so, prithee Tire man set Seignior Snuff a fire, he is a choleric Gentleman, he will take Pepper in the nose instantly, fear not, fore Heaven I wonder they tolerate him so near the Stage.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Faith Doricus thy brain boils, keel it, keel it, or all the fat is in the fire: in the name of Phoebus what merry Genius haunts thee today , thy lips play with Feathers.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Troth they should pick straws before they should be idle,

sp.speaker: Atti,
sp.p: But why, but why dost thou wonder they dare suffer Snuff so near the Stage?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O well recalled, marry Sir seignior Snuff, Monsieur Mew and Caualiero Blurt are three of the most to be feared Auditors that ever ~~

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Pish for shame, stint thy idle chat.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nay dream what so ere your fantasy swims on Phylomuse, I protest in the love you have procured me to bear your friend the Author, I am vehemently fearful, this threefold halter of contempt that chokes the breath of wit, these aforesaid tria sunt omnia, Knights of the Meaw will sit heavy on the skirts of his Scenes, if ~~

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: If what? believe it Doricus his spirit,
Is higher blooded than to quake and pant
At the report of Scoffs Artillery;
Shall he be crest fallen, if some looser brain,
In flux of wit uncivilly befilth
His slight composures? shall his bosom faint
If drunken Censure belch out sower breath,
From Hatreds surfeit on his labours front?
Nay say some half a dozen rancorous breasts
Should plant themselves on purpose to discharge
Imposthumed malice on his latest Scene
Shall his resolve be struck through with the blurt,
Of a goose breath? What imperfect borne?
What short lived Meteor what cold hearted Snow
Would melt in dolour? cloud his muddied eyes
Sink down his jaws, if that some juiceless husk
Some boundless ignorance should on sudden shoot
His gross knobbed burbolt, with that is not so good
Mew, blurt, ha, ha, light Chaffy stuff?
Why gentle spirits what loose waving fan?
What anything would thus be screwed about
With each slight touch of odd Phantasmatas?
No let the feeble palsied lamer joints,
Lean on opinions crutches, let the ~~

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay, nay, nay, Heavens my hope, I cannot smooth this strain,
Wits death I cannot, what a leprous humour
Breaks from rank swelling of these bubbling wits?
Now out upon it: I wonder what tight brain:
Wrung in this custom to maintain Contempt
Against common Censure to give stiff counter buffs
To crack rude scorn even on the very face
Of better audience. Slight is it not odious,
Why hark you honest, honest Phylomuse
(You that endeavour to endear our thoughts,
To the composers spirit) hold this firm:
Music and Poetry were first approved
By common sense; and that which pleased most,
Held most allowed pass: not rules of Art
Were shaped to pleasure, not pleasure to your rules,
Think you if that his scenes took stamp in mint
Of three or four deemed most judicious,
It must enforce the world to currant them
That you must spit defiance on dislike?
Now as I love the light were I to pass
Through public verdict, I should fear my form
Lest aught I offered were unsquared or warped,
The more we know, the more we know we want
What Bayard boulder then the ignorant?
Believe me Phylomuse: i'faith thou must ~~
The best best seal of wit, is wits distrust.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Nay gentle Doricus

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I will hear no more of him, nay and your friend the Author, the composer: the What You Will: seems so fair in his own glass, so straight in his own measure that he talks once of squinting Critics, drunken Censure, splay footed Opinion, juiceless husks, I have done with him, I have done with him.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Pew nay then ~~

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: As if any such unsanctified stuff could find a being among these ingenuous breasts.

sp.speaker: Atti.
sp.p: Come, let pass, let pass, let us see what stuff must cloth our ears: what is the plays name?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: What you Will.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Is it Comedy, Tragedy, Pastoral, Moral, Nocturnal or History?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Faith perfectly neither, but even What you Will, a slight toy, lightly composed, too swiftly finished, ill plotted, worse written, I fear me worst acted, and indeed What You Will.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why I like this vain well now.

sp.speaker: At.
sp.p: Come, we strain the spectators patience in delaying their expected delights. Let us place ourselves within the Curtains, for good faith the Stage is so very little we shall wrong the general eye else very much.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: If you will stay but a little I will accompany you, I have engaged myself to the Author to give a kind of inductive speech to his Comedy.

sp.speaker: At.
sp.l: Away: you neglect yourself, a gentleman ~~

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Tut I have vowed it, I am double charged, go off as it will , I will set fire to it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I will not stand it, may chance recoil, and be not stuffed with salt peter, well mark the report, mark the report.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Nay prithee stay, 'slid the female presence; the Genteletza; the women will put me out.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If they strive to put thee out, do thou endeavour to put them.

sp.speaker: Atti.
sp.p: In good faith if they put thee out of countenance; put thou them out of patience; and hew their ears with hacking imperfect utterance.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Go stand to it, show thyself a tale man of thy tongue, make an honest leg, put off thy Cap with discreet carriage: and so we leave thee to the kind Gentlemen, and most respected Auditors.

sp.l: Nor labours he the favour of the rude,
Nor offers sops unto the Stigian Dog
To force a silence in his viperous tongues:
Nor cares he to insinuate the grace,
Of loathed detraction, nor pursues the love
Of the nice Critics of this squeamish age,
Nor strives he to bear up with every sail
Of floating Censure: nor once dreads or cares
What envious hand his guiltless Muse hath struck,
Sweet breath from tainted stomachs who can suck:
But to the fair proportioned loves of wit,
to the just scale of even peised thoughts:
to those that know the pangs of bringing forth
A perfect feature: to their gentle minds,
that can as soon slight of, as find a blemish,
to those as humbly low as to their feet
I am obliged to bend: to those his Muse
Makes solemn honour, for their wished delight:
He vows industrious sweat shall pale his cheek,
But he will gloss up sleek objects for their eyes:
for those he is ashamed, his best is too bad,
A silly subject too too simply clad
Is all his present, all his ready pay,
for many many debts. give further day
I will give a Proverb, Sufferance giveth ease
so you may once be paid, we once may please.
Exit.

body.stage: Enter Quadratus, Phylus following him with a lute, a Page going before Quadratus with a torch.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: O O I beseech you Sir reclaim his wits,
My Master is mad, stark mad, alas for love,

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: For love? nay and he be not mad for hate,
It is amiable fortune; I tell thee youth
Right rare and geason: strange? mad for love,
O show me him. I will give him reasons straight.
So forcible, so all invincible,
That it shall drag love out: run mad for love?
What mortally exists, on which our hearts
Should be enamoured with such passion?
For love? Come Phylus; come I will change his fate,
In steed of love I will make him mad for hate.
But troth say what strains his madness of?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Fantastical.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Immure him, sconce him, barrecadoe him in it,
Fantastical mad, thrice blessed heart;
Why hark good Phylus: (o that thy narrow sense,
Could but contain me now) all that exists,
Takes valuation from opinion:
A giddy minion now: pish, thy taste is dull,
And canst not relish me, come where is Iacomo?

body.stage: Enter Iacomo unbraced and careless dressed.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Look where he comes: O map of boundless woe!

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Yon gleam is day, darkness, sleep and fear,
Dreams, and the ugly visions of the night
Are beat to hell by the bright palm of light,
Now roams the swain and whistles up the morn:
Deep Silence breaks: all things start up with light,
Only my heart, that endless night and day,
Lies bed red, crippled by coy Lucea,

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: There is a strain law.
Nay now I see he is mad most palpable,
He speaks like a player, hah! poetical.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: The wanton spring lies dallying with the earth,
And powers fresh blood in her decayed veins,
Look how the new sapped branches are in child
With tender infants, how the Sun draws out,
And shapes their moisture into thousand forms
Of sprouting buds, all things that show or breath,
Are now instored, saving my wretched breast,
That is eternally congealed with Ice
Of frozed, despair. O Celia, coy, to nice!

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Still sans question mad?

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: O where doth Piety and Pity rest?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Fetch cords he is irrecoverable, mad, rank mad,
He calls for strange Chimeras fictions
That have no being since the curse of death
Was thrown on man: Pity and Piety,
Whole deign converse with them? alas vain head,
Pity and Piety are long since dead.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Ruin to Chance, and all that strive to stand,
Like swollen Colossus on her tottering Base
Fortune is blind ~~

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: You lie, you lie,
None but a mad man would term Fortune blind,
How can she see to wound desert so right?
Just in the speeding place: to girt lewd brows
With honoured wreath; ha? Fortune blind? away,
How can she hood winked then so rightly see,
To starve rich worth and glut iniquity?

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: O love!

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Love? hang love,
It is the abject out cast of the world,
Hate all things, hate the world, thyself, all men,
Hate knowledge, strive not to be over wise,
It drew destruction into Paradise,
Hate Honour, Virtue, they are baits,
That tice men's hopes to sadder fates,
Hate beauty, every ballad monger,
Can cry his idle soppish humour
Hate riches, wealths a flattering Jack,
A doors to face, mews hind thy back.
He that is poor is firmly sped,
He never shall be flattered
All things are error, dirt and nothing,
Or pant with want or gorged to loathing,
Love only hate, affect no higher
Than praise of heaven, wine, a fire.
Suck up thy days in silent breath,
When their snuffs out come Seignior death.
Now Sir adieu run mad and twilt,
The worst is this my rhymes but spilt.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Thy rhymes are spilt who would not run rank mad,
To see a wandering French man rival, nay
Out strip my suit. He kissed my Celias cheek,

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Why man I saw my dog even kiss thy Celias lips,

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Tomorrow morn they go to wed,

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Well then I know.
Whether tomorrow night they go .

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Say quick.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: To bed

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: I will invoke the triple Heccate,
Make charms as potent as the breath of Fate,
But I will confound the match,

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Nay then good day,
And you be conjuring once I will slink away,

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Boy, could not Orpheus make the stones to dance?

sp.speaker: Phy,
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: By'r'Lady a sweet touch: did he not bring Euridice out of hell with his lute.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: So they say Sir,

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: And thou chanced bring Celias head out of the window with thy Lute, well hazard thy breath: look Sir here is a ditty. It is foully writ slight wit crossed here and there, But where thou findest a blot, there fall a tear.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Fie peace, peace, peace, it hath no passion in it .
O melt thy breath in fluent softer tunes
That every note may seem to trickle down
Like sad distilling tears and make: O God
That I were but a Poet now to express my thoughts
Or a Musician but to sing my thoughts
Or anything but what I am, sing it over once more
My griefs a boundless sea that hath no shore.
sp.stage: He Singes and is answered, from above a Willow garland is flung down and the song ceaseth.
sp.l: Is this my favour? am I crowned with scorn?
Then thus I manumit my slaved condition.
Celia but hear me execrate thy love .
By heaven that once was conscious of my love
By all that is that knows my all was thine
I will pursue with detestation.
Thwart without stretched vehemence of hate
Thy wished Hymen: I will craze my brain
But all dissever all: thy hopes unite
What rage so violent as love turned spite?

body.stage: Enter Randolfo and Andrea with a supplication reading.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Humbly complaining kissing the hands of your excellence your pore orators Randolfo and Andrea beseecheth forbidding of the dishonoured match of their Niece Celia Widow to their Brother ~~
sp.l: O it will do, it will do, it cannot choose but do .

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: What should one say what should one do now, vmph
If she do match with yon same wandering knight
She is but undone, her estimation, wealth ~~

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Nay sir her estimations mounted up
She shall be Ladied and sweet Madamed now.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Be Ladied ha, ha, O could she but recall
The honoured Port of her deceased love;
But think whose wife she was, God wot no knights
But one (that title of) was even a Prince
A Sultan Sollyman: thrice was he made
In dangerous arms Venice prouidetore.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: He was a Merchant, but so bounteous
Valiant, wise, learned, all so absolute
That noughts, was valued praiseful excellent
But in it was he most praiseful excellent.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: O I shall never forget how he went clothed
He would maintain it a base ill used fashion
To bind a Merchant to the sullen habit
Of precise black, chiefly in Venice state.
Where Merchants guilt the top
And therefore should you have him pass the bridge
Up the Rialto like a soldier
(As still he stood a Potestate at sea)~~

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: In a black beaver felt, ash colour plain
A Florentine cloth of silver Jerkin, sleeves
White satin cut on tinsel, then long stock. ~~

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: French pains embroidered, Gold smiths work, O God
Methinks I see him now how he would walk:
With what a jolly presence he would pace
Round the Rialto. Well he is soon forgot
A straggling sir in his rich bed must sleep
Which if I cannot cross. I will curse and weep.
Shall I be plain as Truth I love your Sister
My education birth and wealth deserves her
I have no cross, no rub to stop my suit
But Lauardur is a knight, that strikes all mute.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Aye there is the devil, she must be Ladied now.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: O ill nursed custom no sooner is the wealthy Merchant dead
His wife left great in fair possessions
But giddy rumour grasps it twixt his teeth
And shakes it bout our ears. Then thither flock
A rout of crazed fortunes whose cracked states
Gape to be soddered up by the rich mass
Of the deceased labours, and now and then
The troupe of I beseech and I protest
And believe it sweet is mixed with two or three
Hopeful, well stocked, neat clothed Citizens

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: But as we see the son of a Divine
Seldom proves Preacher, or a Lawyers son
Rarely a pleader, (for they strive to Run
A various fortune from their Ancestors)
So it is right geason for the Merchants widow,
To be the Citizens loved second spouse.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Variety of objects please us still
One dish though never so cooked doth quickly fill.
When diverse cates the palates sense delight
And with fresh taste creates new appetite
Therefore my widow she cashiers the blacks
Forswears turns of the furred gowns, and surveys
The bedroll of her suitors thinks and thinks,
And straight her questing thoughts springs up a knight,
Have after then a maine the game is afoot
The match clapped up, tut it is the knight must it.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Then must my pretty peat be Fanned and Coached.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Muffed Masked and Ladied, with my more than most sweet Madam,
But how long doth this perfume of sweet Madam last?
Faith it is but a wash sent. My Riotous sir
Begins to crack Gestes on his Ladies front,
Touches her new stamped gentry, takes a glut
Keeps out, abandons home, and spends and spends
Till stock be melted, then sir takes up here
Takes up there, till nowhere aught is left.
Then for the Low countries, hay for the French,
And so (to make up rhyme) god night sweet wench.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: By blessedness we will stop this fatal lot.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: But how: but how?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Why stay let us think a plot.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Was not Albano Beletzo honourable rich?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Not peered in Venice, for birth, fortune love.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: It is scarce three months since fortune gave him dead.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: In the black fight in the Venetian gulf.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: You hold a truth.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Now what a giglet is this Celia?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: To match so sudden so unworthily?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Why she might have ~~

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: who might not Celia have?
The passionate enamoured Iacomo

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: The passionate enamoured Iacomo.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Of honoured linage, and not meanly rich.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: The sprightful Piso, the great Florentine, Aurelius Tuber.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: And to leave these all,
And wed a wandering Knight Sir Lauerdure
A God knows what?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Brother she shall not, shall our blood be mongrelled with the corruption of a straggling French?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Saint Mark she shall not,

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: She shall not fathers by; our brother souls.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Good day.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Wish me good day? it stands in idle stead,
My Celia is lost, all my good days are dead.
Hark Lorenzo Celso the loose Venice Duke,
Is going to bed it is now a forward morn
Fore he take rest. O strange transformed sight,
When Princes make night day the day there night.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Come we will petition him,

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Away away,
He scorns all plaints makes jest of serious suit.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Fall out as it it will I am resolved to it.
sp.stage: Enter the Duke coupled with a Lady, two couples more with them, the men having tobacco pipes in their hands, the women sit, they dance a round. The Petition is delivered up by Randolfo, the Duke lights his tobacco pipe with it and goes out dancing.
sp.l: Saint Mark Saint Mark.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Did not I tell you, loose no more rich time,
What can one get but mire from a swine?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Let us work a cross, we will fame it all about
The French Man is gelded.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: O that is absolute.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Fie on it away, she knows too well it is false,
I fear it too well. No no I have it will strongly do it ,
Who knows Francisco Soranza?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Pish, pish, why what of him?

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Is he not wondrous like your deceased kinsman Albano.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Exceedingly the strangest nearly like
In voice, in gesture face in ~~

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Nay he hath Albanos imperfection too,
And stuts when he is vehemently moved.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Observe me then, him would I have disguised,
Most perfect like Albano: giving out,
Albano saved by swimming (as in faith
It is known he swam most strangely) rumour him,
This morn arrived in Venice, here to lurk
As having heard the forward Nuptials,
To observe his wife's most infamous lewd haste
And to revenge ~~

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: I have it , I have it , I have it , it will be invincible.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: By this means now some little time we catch,
For better hopes at least disturb the match.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: I will to Francisco.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Brother Adrian
You have our brothers picture, shape him to it.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Precise in each but Tassel, fear it not.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Saint Mark then prosper once, our hopeful plot.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Good souls, good day, I have not slept last night,
I will take a nap, then pell mell broach all spite.

body.stage: One knocks: Lauerdure draws the Curtains sitting on his bed apparelling himself, his trunk of apparel standing by him.

sp.speaker: Laue.
sp.l: Ho Bydett Lackey.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.l: Seignior?

body.stage: Enter Bydett with Water and a Towel.

sp.speaker: Laue.
sp.l: See who knocks, look you boy, peruse their habits, return perfect notice, la la ly ro.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.l: Quadratus.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Quadratus, mordieu, ma vie: I lay not at my lodging tonight , I will not see him now on my soul, he is in his old Perpetuana suit, I am not within.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: He is fair, gallant, rich, neat as a Bride groom, fresh as a new minted six pence, with him Lampatho Doria, Symplicius Faber

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: And in good clothes.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.l: Accoutred worthy a presence.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Godso: my gold wrought Waist coat and Night cap open my Trunk, lay my richest suit on the top, my Velvet slippers, cloth of gold gamashes, where are my cloth of silver hose, lay them.~~

sp.speaker: Bydet.
sp.l: At pawn sir.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: No sir, I do not bid you lay them at pawn Sir.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.l: No sir, you need not for they are there already.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Mor du garzone: set my richest Gloves, Garters, Hats, just in the way of their eyes, so let them in, observe me withal duteous respect, let them in.

body.stage: Enter Quadratus, Lampatho Doria and Simplicius Faber

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Phoebus, Phoebe Sun, Moon, and seven Stars make thee the dilling of Fortune, my sweet Lauerdure, my rich French blood, have ye dear rogue, hast any pudding Tobacco?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: God morrow Seignior.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Monsieur Lauerdure, do you see that Gentleman, he goes but in black Satin as you see, but by Hellicon he hath a cloth of Tissue wit, he breaks a jest, ha, he will rail against the Court till the gallants ~~ O God he is very Nectar, if you but sip of his love, you were immortal, I must needs make you known to him: I will induce your love with dear regard. Seignior Lampatho here is is a French Gentleman Monsieur Lauerdure a Traveller, a beloved of heaven, courts your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Sir I protest I not only take distinct notice of your dear rarities of exterior presence, but also I protest I am most vehemently enamoured, and very passionately dote on your inwatd adornments and abilities of spirit, I protest I shall be proud to do you most obsequious vassalage.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Is not this rare now: now by Gorgons head,
I gape and am struck stiff in wonderment,
At sight of these strange beasts. You Chamblet youth,
Symplicius Faber that Hermaphrodite,
Party par pale, that bastard Mongrel soul,
Is nought but admiration and applause,
Of you Lampatho Doria, a fusty cask,
Devote to mouldy customs of hoard old,
Doth he but speak, O tones of heaven itself ,
Doth he once write, O Iesu admirable
Cries out Symplicius: then Lampatho spits,
And says faith it is good. But O to mark yon thing
Sweat to unite acquaintance to his friend,
Labour his praises and endear his worth
With titles all as formally tricked forth,
As the Cap of a Dedicatory Epistle,
Then sir to view Lampatho, he protests,
Protests and vows, such sudden heat of love,
That O it were warmth enough of mirth to dry,
The stintless tears of old Heraclitus,
Make Nysbe to laugh.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I protest I shall be proud to give you proof, I hold a most religious affiance with your love.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Nay gentle Seignior:

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Let me not live else, I protest I will strain my utmost sineus, in strengthening your precious estimate, I protest, I will do all rights in all good offices that friendship can touch, or amplest virtue deserve.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: I protest believe him not, I will beg thee Lauerdure
For a concealed Idiot if thou credit him,
He is a Hyena and with Civet scent
Of perfumed words, draws to make a prey
For laughter of thy credit. O this hot crackling love
That blazeth on an instant, flames me out
On the least puff of kindness, with protest, protest,
Catzo I dread these hot protests, that press
Come on so fast, no, no, away, away,
You are a common friend or will betray.
Let me clip amity, that is got with suit,
I hate this whorish love that is prostitute.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Horn on my Tailor, could he not bring home,
My Satin Taffeta, or Tissue suit:
But I must needs be clothed in Woollen thus.
Bydett, what says he for my Silver hose?
And Prim rose Satin Doublet, Gods my life,
Gives he no more observance to my body.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O in that last suit gentle Lauerdure,
Visit my lodging: by Appollos front
Do but inquire my name; O straight they will say
Lampatho suits himself in such a hose.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Mark that Quadratus

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Consorts himself with such a doublet.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Good, good, good, O Iesu admirable.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: La la ly ro Sir.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: O Pallas! Quadratus, hark, hark, a most complete phantasma, a most ridiculous humour, prithee shoot him through and through with a jest, make him lie by the lee, thou Basilisco of wit.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O Iesu, admirably well spoken, Angelical tongue.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Gnathonicall Coxcomb,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Nay pre thee, 'sfoot fear not he is no edge tool, you may jest with him.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: No edge tool, O!

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Tones of heaven itself.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Tones of heaven itself.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: By blessedness I thought so.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Nay when, when?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Why thou Pole head, thou Janus, thou poltroon, thou protest, thou Ear wig that wrigglest into men's brains: thou dirty cur that be mirest with thy fawning, thou ~~

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Obscure me, or ~~

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Synior Lauerdure, by the heart of an honest man, this Iebusite, this confusion to him, this worse than I dare to name, abuseth thee most incomprehensibly; is this your protest of most obsequious vassalage, protest to strain your utmost sum, your most ~~

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: So Phoebus warm my brain, I will rhyme thee dead,
Look for the Satire, if all the sower juice
Of a tart brain, can souse thy estimate,
I will pickle thee.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Ha, he mount Chirall on the wings of fame.
A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse,
Look thee I speak play scraps. Bydet I will down
Sing, sing, or stay we will quasse or anything
Riuo, Saint Mark let us talk as loss as air
Unwind youths colours, display ourselves
So that you envy starved Cur may yelp
And spend his chaps at our Fantasticness.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: O Lord Quadratus

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Away Idolater, why you don Kynsayder
Thou Canker eaten rusty cur, thou snaffle
To freer spirits.
Thinkst thou a libertine, am ungived breast
Scorns not the shackles of thy envious clogs
You will traduce us unto public scorn.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: By this hand I will.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: A fuotra for thy hand, thy heart, thy brain,
Thy hate, thy malice, Envy, grinning spite
Shall a free borne that holds Antipathy ~~

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Antipathy.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: A native hate unto the curse of man, bare pated servitude,
Quake at the frowns of a ragged Satirist
A scrubbing railer whose course hardened fortune
Grating his hide, galling his starved ribs
Sits howling at Deserts more battle fate
Who out of dungeon of his black Despairs
Scowls at the fortune of the fairer Merit.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Tut Via let all run glib and square.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: 'Sfoot he cogs and cheats your simpler thoughts,
My spleen is a fire in the heat of hate
I bear these gnats that hum about our ears,
And sting blister our credits in obscured shades.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Pewte bougra la, la, la, tit shaugh
Shall I forbear to caper, sing, or vault
To wear fresh clothes or wear perfumed sweets
To trick my face, or glory in my fate,
To abandon natural propensitudes
My fancies humour, for a stiff jointed,
Tattered nasty tabor faced, puh, la, la, ly ro

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Now by thy Ladies cheek I honour thee
My rich free blood, O my dear libertine
I could suck the juice, the syrup of thy lip,
For thy most generous thought. My Elysium.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: O Sir you are so square you scorn reproof.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: No sir should discreet Mastigophoros
Or the dear spirit acute Canaidus
(That Aretine; that most of me beloved
Who in the rich esteem I prize his soul
I term myself) should these once menace me
Or curb, my humours with well governed check
I should with most industrious regard,
Observe abstain, and curb my skipping lightness
But when an arrogant odd impudent,
A blushless fore head only out of sense.
Of his own wants, balls in malignant questing
At others means of waving gallantry ~~
Pipht foutra.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I rail at none you well squared Syneor.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: I cannot tell, it is now grown fashion,
What is out of railing is out of fashion:
A man can scarce put on a tucked up cap
A buttoned frizado suit, scarce eat good meat,
Anchovies, caviar but he is Satired
And termed Fantastical by the muddy spawn
Of slimy Newts, when troth, Fantasticness,
That which the natural Sophysters term
Phantusia incomplexa is a function
Even of the bright immortal part of man.
It is the common pass, the sacred door,
Unto the privy chamber of the soul
That barred nought passeth past the baser Court:
Of outward sense by it the inamorate ,
Most lively thinks he sees the absent beauties
Of his loved mistress.
By it we shape a new creation,
Of things as yet unborn, by it we feed:
Our ravenous memory, our intention feast
'slid he that is not fantastical is a beast.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Most Fantastical protection of Fantasticness.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Faith it is good.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: So it be fantastical it is wits life blood.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Come Seignior my legs are girt.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Fantastically.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: After a special humour a new cut.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Why then it is, rare, it is excellent 'sfoot
If I were to be hanged I would be choked
Fantastically he can scarce be saved
That is not fantastical, I stand firm to it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nay then sweet sir give reason, come on, when.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: It is hell to run in common base of men.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Hast not run thyself out of breath bully.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: If I have not jaded thy ears more than I have tired my tongue, I could run discourse, put him out of his full pace.
sp.l: I could pour speech till thou criedest ho, but troth,
I dread a glut, and I confess much love
To freer gentry whose pert agile spirits
Is too much frost bit numbed with ill strained snibs
Hath tender reached my speech. By Brutus blood
He is a turf that will be slave to man.
But he is a beast that dreads his mistress fan.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Come all mirth and solace, capers, healths and whiffs
Tomorrow are my nuptials celebrate:
All friends all friends.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I protest ~~

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Nay leave protests, pluck out your snarling fangs. When thou hast means be Fantastical and sociable; go to, here is my hand and you want forty shillings I am your Mcenas though not Atauis Edite regibus.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why content and I protest ~~

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: I will no protest.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Well and I do not leave these fopperies do not lend me forty shillings, and there is my hand, I embrace you, love you, nay adore thee, for by the juice of worm wood, thou hast a bitter brain.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: You Simplicius? wilt leave that staring fellow Admiration and Adoration of thy acquaintance wilt. A scorn out it is odious, too eager a defence argues a strong opposition, and too vehement a praise, draws a suspicion of others worthy disparagement.
sp.l: Set tapers to bright day, it ill befits
Good wines can vent themselves, and not good wits.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Good truth I love you, and with the grace of Heaven,
I will be very civil and ~~

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Fantastical.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: I will be something , I have a concealed humour in me and it were broached it would spurt i'faith.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Come then Saint Mark let us be as light as air
As fresh and jocund as the breast of May:
I prithee good French knight good plump cheeked chub
Run some French passage, come let us see thy vain,
Dances scenes, and songs, royal entertain.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Petite lacque page, page, Bydet sing
Give it the French jerk, quick spart, lightly, ha,
Ha here is a turn unto my Lucea.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Stand stiff ho stand, take footing firm stand sure
For if thou fall before thy mistress
Thy manhood is damned; stand firm ~~ ho good, so, so.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Come now via aloune to Celia.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Stay take an old rhyme first though dry and lean
It will serve to close the stomach of the Scene.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: This is thy humour to berhyme us still,
Never so slightly pleased but out they fly.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: They are mine own, no gleaned Poetry,
My fashion is known , out rhyme take it as you list:
A fico, for the sower browed Zoilist
Music, Tobacco, Sack and Sleep,
The tide of Sorrow backward keep.
If thou art sad at others fate,
Riuo drink deep give care the mate,
On us the end of time is come,
Fond fear of that we cannot shun,
Whilst quickest sense doth freshly last,
Clip time about, hug pleasure fast.
The Sisters ravel out our twine,
He that knows little is most divine.
Error deludes; whole beat this hence,
Nought is known but by exterior sense,
Let glory blazon others deed,
My blood then breath craves better meed,
Let twattling fame cheated others rest,
I am no dish for Rumours feast.
Let honour others hope abuse,
I will nothing have so nought will loose:
I will strive to be nor great nor small,
To live nor die, fate helmeth all,
When I can breath no longer then,
Heaven take all, there put Amen.
How is it, how is it?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Faith so, so, telamant, quelamant as it please Opinion to currant it.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Why then via let us walk,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I must give notice to an odd pedant as we pass of my nuptials, I use him for he is obscure and shall marry us in private, I have many enemies but secrecy is the best evasion from envy.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Holds it tomorrow ?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Aye firm absolute,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I will say amen if the Priest be mute.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Epythalamiums will I singe my chuck,
Go on, spend freely, out on dross it is muck.

body.stage: Enter a School master, draws the curtains behind with, Battus Nows, Slip, Nathaniell and Holifernes Pippo school boys, sitting with books in their hands.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Salve Magister.

p.foreign: Saluete pueri estote salui, vos saluere exopto vobis salutem, Batte my fili, fili mi Batte.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Quid vis.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Stand forth repeat your lesson with out book.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: A noun is the name of a thing that may be seen felt heard or understood.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Good boy, on on,

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Of nouns some be substantives and some be substantives.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Adjectives.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Adjectives, a noun substantive ether is proper to the thing that it betokeneth.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Well to numbers.

sp.speaker: Battus.
sp.p: In Nouns be two numbers, the Singular and the Plural, the Singular number speaketh of one as Lapis a Stone, the Plural speaketh of more than one, as Lapides stones.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Good child, now thou art past Lapides Stones, proceed to the cases Nous say you next Nous where is your lesson Nous.

sp.speaker: Nous,
sp.l: I am in a verb forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Say on for sooth say say.

sp.speaker: Nous.
sp.p: A verb is a part of speech declined with mood and tense and betokeneth doing as Amo I love,

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How many kind of verbs are there?

sp.speaker: Nous.
sp.l: 2. Personal and impersonal,

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Of verbs personals, how many kinds.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: Five, Active Passive Neuter Deponent and Common. A Verb Active endeth in O and betokeneth to do as Amo I love and by putting to R it may be a passive as Amour I am loved.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Very good child, now learn to know the Deponent and common: Say you Slip.

l.foreign: Cedant arma tog, concedant lauria lingu.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What part of speech is lingua, inflect, inflect

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Singulariter, nominatiuo Hec lingua.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Why is lingua the Feminine gender?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Forsooth because it is the Feminine gender.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Ha thou Ass, thou Dolt, Idem per idem mark it: lingua is declined with Hec the Feminine, because it is a household stuff particularly belonging, and most commonly resident under the roof of Women's mouths. Come on you Nathaniell say you, say you next, not too fast, say treatably, say.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Faster, faster.

l.foreign: Vt, sal, sol, ren and splen:
Bes, cres, pres and pes, glis, glirens habens genetiuo,
Mos, flos, ros and tros, muns, dens, mons, pons.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Rup, tup, snup, slup, bor, hor, cor, mor:holla, holla, holla you Holifernes Pippo put him down, wipe your Nose: fie on your sleeve, where is your Muckender your Grand mother gave you? well say on, say on.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.l: Pray Master what word is this?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ass, Ass.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.l: As in presenti perfectum format in, in, in.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: In what Sir?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.l: Perfectum format in what Sir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: In what Sir in avi

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.l: In what Sir in avi
Vt no, nas, naui, vocito, vocitas, voci, voci, voci ~~

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What is next?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.l: Voci, What is next?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Why thou ungracious child, thou simple animal, thou barnacle. Nous snare him, take him up, and you were my father you should up.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Indeed I am not your Father, O Lord now for God sake; let me go out, my mother told a thing, I shall bewray all else. Hark you Master, my Grand mother entreats you to come to dinner Tomorrow morning.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I say untruss take him up, Nous dispatch what not perfect in an Ass in present

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.l: In truth I will be as perfect an Ass in present as any of this Company with the grace of god law, this once, this once, and I do so any more

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I say hold him up.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Ha let me say my prayers first. You know not what you have done now, all the syrup of my brain is run into my buttocks and ye spill the juice of my wit well, ha sweet, ha sweet, honey barbary sugar sweet Master.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Sans tricks trifles, delays, demurrers procrastinations or retardations mount him, mount him.

body.stage: Enter Quadratus Lampatho Lauerdure and Simplicius

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Be merciful my gentle Seignior

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: We will sue his pardon out.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: He is reprieved: and now Apollo bless your brains Facundius and Elaborate elegance make your presence gracious in the eyes of your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: You must along with us, lend private ear.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: What is your name.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.l: Holifernes Pippo.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Who gave you that name. Nay let me alone for spousing of a scholar.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.l: My godfathers and god mothers in my baptism.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Truly gallants I am enamoured on thee boy wilt thou serve me.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.l: Yes and please my grand mother when I come to years of discretion.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: If you have a propensitude to him, he shall be for you: I was solicited to grant him leave to play the Lady in comedies presented by Children, but I knew his voice was too small and his stature too low, sing, sing a treble Holifernes sing.

sp.l: A very small sweet voice I will assure you.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: It is smelly sweet indeed .

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: A very pretty Child, hold up thy head, there, buy thee some plums.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Nay they must play, you go a long with us.

l.foreign: Ludendi venia est petita and concessa.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Gratias.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Pippo is my page, how like you him, ha has he not a good face, ha.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Exceeding amiable; come away,
I long to see my love my Celia

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Carry my rapier hold up so, good child, stay gallants vmph a sweet face.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I relish not this mirth, my spirit is untwist,
My heart is ravelled out in discontents,
I am deep thoughtful, and I shoot my soul
Through all creation of omnipotence.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: What art melancholy Lamp I will feed thy humour
I will give thee reason straight to hang thyself
Mark it mark it : in heavens handiwork theirs nought
Believe it.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: In heavens handiwork there is nought
None more vile, accursed, reprobate to bliss
Than man, and among men a scholar most.
Things only fleshly sensitive, an Ox or Horse,
They live and eat, and sleep, and drink, and die
And are not touched with recollections
Of things over past or staggered infant doubts
Of things succeeding: but leave the manly beasts,
And give but pence a piece to have a sight:
Of beastly man now.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: What so Lampatho good truth I will not pay your Ordinary if you come not.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Dost thou hear that voice. I will make a parrot now,
As good a man as he in fourteen nights
I never heard him vent a syllable:
Of his own creating since I knew the use
Of eyes and ears? Well he is perfect blessed,
Because a perfect beast. I will gage my heart
He knows no difference essential
Twixt my dog and him. The whoreson sot is blessed
Is rich in ignorance makes fair usance on it
And every day augments his barbarism
So love me Calmness I do envy him forts,
I was a scholar: seven use full springs
Did I deflower in quotations
Of crossed opinions bout the soul of man
The more I learnt the more I learnt to doubt
Knowledge and wit faiths foes, turn faith about

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay come good Seignior I stay all the gentlemen here, I would fain give my pretty page a pudding pie.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Honest Epicure
Nay mark list delight, delight my spaniel slept, whilst I bausd leaves.
Tossed over the dunces pored on the old print
Of titled words, and still my spaniel slept.
Whilst I wasted lamp-oil, bated my flesh
Shrunk up my veins, and still my spaniel slept.
And still I held converse with Zabarell
Aquinas Scotus, and the musty saw
Of antic Donate, still my spaniel slept
Still on went I, first an sit anima
Then and it were mortal, O hold hold
At that they are at brain buffets fell by the ears,
A maine pell mell together, still my spaniel slept.
Then whether it were Corporeal, Local, fixed,
Extraduce, but whether it had free will
Or no, ho Philosophers
Stood banding factions all so strongly propped,
I staggered, knew not which was firmer part.
But thought, quoted, read, observed and pried,
Stuffed noting books, and still my spaniel slept.
At length he waked and yawned and by yon sky,
For aught I know he knew as much as I.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Delicate good Lampatho come away. I assure you I will give but two pence more.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How, it was created, how the soul exists
One talks of motes, the soul was made of motes,
An other fire, the other light, a third a spark of Star like nature
Hippo water, Anaximenes air,
Aristoxenus Music; Critias I know not what,
A company of odd phrenetici
Did eat my youth, and when I crept abroad,
Finding my numbness in this nimble age,
I fell a-railing , but now soft and slow,
I know, I know nought, but I nought do know,
What shall I do, what plot, what course pursue?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Why turn a Temporist row with the tide,
Pursue the cut, the fashion of the age,
Well here is my Scholars course, first get a School,
And then a ten pound Cure, keep both, then buy,
(Stay marry, Aye marry) then a farm or so,
Serve God and Mammon, to the Devil go,
Affect some sect, Aye it is the sect is it,
So thou canst seem it is held the precious wit:
And O if thou canst get some higher seat,
Where thou mayst sell your holy portion,
(Which charitable providence ordained
In sacred bounty for a blessed use)
Alien the glebe, entail it to thy loins,
Entomb it in thy grave
Past resurrection to his native use.
Now if there be a hell, and such swine saved,
Heaven take all, that is all my hopes have craved.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: My Simplicias Master.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Your Master Simplicius

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Has come to you to sent.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Has sent to me to come.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Ha, ha has bought me a fine dagger, and a Hat and a Feather, I can say As in presenti now.

sp.l: Quadratus Quadratus away, away.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: We come sweet gallants; and grumbling hate lie still
And turn Fantastic: he that climbs a hill
Must wheel about, the ladder to account
Is sly dissemblance, he that means to mount,
Must lie all level in the prospective
Of eager sighted greatness, thou wouldst thrive,
The Venice state is young, loose, and unknit,
Can relish nought but luscious vanities
Go fit his tooth, O glavering flattery,
How potent art thou: front look brisk and sleek,
That such base dirt as you should dare to reek,
In Princes nostrils. Well my scene is long.
Quadratus.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: I come hot bloods, those that their state would swell,
Must bear a counter face: the devil and hell
Confound them all, that is all my prayers exact,
So ends our chat, sound Music for the Act.

body.stage: Enter Francisco half dressed, in his black doublet and round cap, the the rest rich, Iacomo bearing his hat and feather? Adrean his doublet and band, Randolfo his cloak and staff, they cloth Francisco whilst Bydet creeps in and observes them. Much of of this done whilst the Act is playing.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: For God sake remember to take special marks of me, or you will never be able to know me.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: Why man?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Why good faith I scarce know myself already methinks I should remember to forget myself, now I am so shining brave. Indeed Francisco was always a sweet youth, for I am a Persumer, but thus brave? I am an alien to it, would you make me like the drowned Albano must I bear it mainly up, must I be he .

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: What else man? O what else?

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: I warrant you, give him but fair rich clothes,
He can be taken , reputed anything ,
Apparail is grown a God and goes more neat,
Makes men of rags, which straight he bears aloft,
Like patched up scar Crows to affright the rout
Of the Idolatrous vulgar, that worship Images,
Stand awed and bare scalped at the gloss of silks,
Which like the glorious Aiax of Lincoln's Inn
Surveyed with wonder by me when I lay,
Factor in London: laps up nought but filth
And excrements, that bear the shape of men,
Whose inside every day would peck and tear,
But that vain scare crow clothes entreats forbear.

sp.speaker: Fran,
sp.l: You would have me take upon me Albano
A valiant gallant Venetian Burgomasco
Well my beard, my feather, short sword and my oath
Shall do it fear not. What I know a number
By the sole warrant of a Lappy beard,
A rain beat plume, and a good chop filling oath,
With an odd French shrug, and by the Lotted or so,
He leapt into sweet Captain with such ease,
As you would ~~ fear it not, I will gage my heart I will it,
How sits my Hat, ha, Jack doth my feather wag.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Methinks now in the common sense of fashion,
Thou shouldest grow proud, and like a fore horse view,
None but before hand gallants, as for sides
And those that rank in equal file with thee,
Study a faint salute, give a strange eye,
But as to those in rear ward O be blind,
The world wants eyes, it cannot see behind.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Where is the strumpet, where is the hot veined French
Lives not Albano hath Celia so forgot,
Albanos love, that she must forth with wed,
A run about, a skipping French man ~~

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Now you must grow in heat and stut.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: An odd phantasma, a beggar, a Sir, a who who who what you will a straggling go go go gunds, f f f f 'sfoot

sp.speaker: Adrian.
sp.l: Passing like him, passing like him, O it will strike all dead.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I am ravished it will be peerless exquisite,
sp.l: Let him go out instantly.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: O not till twilight, mean time I will prop up
The tottering Rumour of Albanos scape.
And safe arrival, it begins to spread,
If this plot live Frenchman thy hopes are dead.

sp.speaker: Bydet.
sp.l: And if it live strike off this little head.

body.stage: Enter Albano with Slip his Page.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Can it be? is it possible? is it within the bounds of faith? O villainy.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: The clapper of Rumour strikes on both sides ringing out the French knight is in firm possession of my Mistress your wife.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Is it possible I should be dead so soon?
In her affects, how long is it since our shipwreck?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Faith I have little arithmetic in me, yet I remember the storm made me cast up perfectly the whole sum of all I had received, three days before I was liquored soundly my guts were rinsed for the heavens: I look as pale ever since as if I had taken the diet this spring.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: But how long is it since our ship wrack?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Marry since we were hung by the heels on the batch of Cycily to make a jail delivery of the sea in our maws it is just three months: shall I speak like a Poet? Thrice hath the horned moan

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Talk not of horns. O Celia how oft
(When thou hast laid thy cheek upon my breast
And with lascivious petulancy sewed.
For Hymeneal dalliance marriage rights)
O then how oft with passionate protests
And zealous vows hast thou obliged thy love,
In dateless bands unto Albanos breast?
Then did I but mention second Marriage
With what a bitter hate would she inveigh
Against retailed wedlocks. O would she lisp
If you should die, then would she slide a tear,
And with a wanton languishment in twist
Her hands) O God and you should die. Marry?
Could I love life; my dear Albano dead
Should any Prince possess his widows bed?
And now see, see, I am but rumoured drowned.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: She will make you Prince, your worship must be crowned
O master you know the woman is the weaker creature,
She must have a prop: the maid is the brittle metal
Her head is quickly cracked: the wife is queasy stomached
She must be fed with novelties; but then what is your widow,
Custom is a second nature I say no more but think you the rest.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: If love be holy, if that mystery,
Of co-united hearts be sacrament?
If the unbounded goodness have infused.
A sacred ardour if a mutual love
Into our Species of those amorous joys,
Those sweets of life, those comforts even in death
Spring from a cause above our reasons reach?
If that clear flame deduce his heat from heaven?
It is like his cause is eternal always one
As is the instiller of divinest love
Unchanged by time immortal maugre death.
But O it is grown a figment: love a jest:
A comic Poesy: the soul of man is rotten
Even to the core no sound affection.
Our love is hollow vaulted, stands on props,
Of circumstance, profit or ambitious hopes.
The other tissue Gown or Chain of pearl
Makes my coy minx to nuzzle twixt the breasts
Of her lulled husband, the other Carcanet,
Deflowers that Ladies bed: one hundred more
Marries that loathed blowze, one ten pound odds
In promised jointure makes the hard palmed sire,
Enforce his daughters tender lips to start
At the sharpe touch of some loathed stubbed beard,
The first pure time the golden age is fled,
Heaven knows I lie it is now the age of gold,
For it all marreth and even virtues sold.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Master will you trust me and I will.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Yes boy I will trust thee, babes and fools I will trust
But servants faith, wives love, or females lust,
A usurer and the devil sooner. Now were I dead,
Methinks I see a huff cap swaggering sir,
Pawning my plate, my jewels, mortgage? Nay
Selling out right the purchase of my brows,
Whilst my poor fatherless lean tottered son,
My gentries relics, my houses only prop,
Is sawed a sunder, lies forlorn, all bleak,
Unto the griefs of sharpe Necessities
Whilst his father in law, his father in Devil, or d d d d Devil,
f f f father,
Or who who who who; What you will
When is the marriage morn?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Even next rising sun.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Good, good, good, go to my brother Adrian
Tell him I will lurk, stay, tell him I will lurk, stay,
Now is Albanos marriage bed new hung
With fresh rich Curtains, now are my valence up ,
Embossed with orient Pearl, my Grandsires gift,
Now are the Lawn sheets fumed with Violets,
To fresh the pallid lascivious appetite,
Now work the Cooks, the pastry sweats with slaves,
The March panes glitter, now now the musicians
Hover with nimble sticks over squeaking crowds,
Tickling the dried guts of a Mewing Cat,
sp.p: The Taylors, Starchers, Seamsters, Butchers, Poulterers, Mercers, all, all, all, now now now, none think a me, the f f f French is te f f f fine man, the p p p pock man, the

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Peace, peace, stand concealed, yonder by all descriptions is he would be husband of my Mistress: your wife hah meat hah.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Godso, so, so, soul that is my velvet cloak.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: O peace, observe him, hah.

body.stage: Enter Lauerdure and Bidett talking, Quadratus, Lampatho, Simplicius, Pedant and Holifernes Pippo

sp.speaker: Bidet.
sp.p: It is most true Sir, I heard all, I saw all, I tell all, and I hope you believe all, the sweet Francisco Soranza the Perfumer is by your rival Iacomo and your two brothers that must be, when you have married your wife, that shall be.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.l: With the grace of Heaven

sp.speaker: Bidett.
sp.p: Disguised so like the drowned Albano to cross your suit, that by my little honesty it was great consolation to me to observe them, passion of joy, of hope. O excellent cried Andrea passingly cried Randolfo unparalleled lisps Iacomo good, good, good, says Andrea now stut says Iacomo now stut says Randolfo whilst the ravished Perfumer had like to have watered the seams of his breeches for extreme pride of their applause.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Seest I will to Celia and maugre the nose of her friends, wed her: bed her, my first son shall be a Captain, and his name shall be what it please his God fathers, the second if he have a face bad enough , a Lawyer, the third a Merchant, and the fourth if he be maimed, dull brained, or hard shaped, a scholar, for that is your fashion.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Get them, get them man first; now by the wantonness of the night, if I were a wench I would not have thee, wert thou an heir, nay (which is more) a fool.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why I can rise high, a straight leg, a plump thigh, a full vain, a round cheek, and when it pleaseth the fertility of my chin to be delivered of a beard, it will not wrong my kissing, for my lips are rebels, and stand out.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Ho but there is an old fusty Proverb, these great talkers are never good doers.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why what a babel arrogance is this?
Men will put by the very stock of fate,
They will thwart the destiny of marriage,
Strive to disturb the sway of providence,
They will do it?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Come, you will be snarling now.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: As if we had free will in supernatural
Effects, and that our love or hate
Depended not on causes above the reach
Of human stature.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: I think I shall not lend you forty shillings now.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Dirt upon dirt, fear is beneath my shoe,
Dreadless of racks, strappados, or the sword,
Maugre Informer and sly intelligence,
I will stand as confident as Hercules
And with a frightless resolution,
Rip up and lance our times impieties.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Godso peace.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Open a bounteous ear for I will be free,
Ample as Heaven give my speech more room,
Let me unbrace my breasts, strip up my sleeves,
Stand like an executioner to vice,
To strike his head off with the keener edge,
Of my sharpe spirit.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Room and good licence, come on, when, when.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now is my fury mounted, fix your eyes,
Intend your senses, bend your listening up,
For I will make greatness quake, I will taw the hide
Of thick skinned Hugeness

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: It is most gracious we will observe thee calmly.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Hang on thy tongues end, come on prithee do .

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I will see you hanged first, I thank you Sir, I will none,
This is the strain that chokes the theatres:
That makes them crack with full stuffed audience,
This is your humour only in request
Forsooth to rail, this brings your ears to bed,
This people gape for, for this some do stare
This some would hear, to crack the Authors neck,
This admiration and applause pursues,
Who cannot rail, my humours changed it is clear,
Pardon I will none, I prise my joints more dear.

sp.speaker: Bidet.
sp.p: Master, Master, I have descried the Perfumer in Albanos disguise, look you, look you, rare sport, rare sport.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: I can contain my impatience no longer, you Monsieur Cavalier Saint Dennis you Capricious Sir, Seignior Caranto French brawl you that must marry Celia Galanto is Albano drowned now? Go wander, avaunt Knight errant Celia shall be no Cuckquean, my heir no beggar, my plate no pawn, my land no mortgage, my wealth no food for thy luxuries, my house no harbour for thy Comrades my bed no booty for thy lusts, my anything shall be thy nothing, go hence pack, pack, avaunt, caper, caper, aloun, aloun, pass by, pass by, cloak your nose, away, vanish, wander depart, slink by away.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Hark you perfumer, tell Iacomo Randulfo and Adrean it will not do, look you say no more, but it will not do.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: What perfumer? what Iacomo

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Nay assure thee honest Perfumer good Francisco we know all man, go home to thy Civet Box, look to the profit, commodity or emolument of thy Mus cats tail, go clap on your round Cap, my what do you lack sir, for i'faith good rogue all is descried.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: What Perfumer? what Mus cat? what Francisco what do you lack, is it not enough that you kissed my wife?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Enough.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Aye enough , and may be, I fear me too much, but you must flout me, deride me, scoff me, keep out, touch not my porch, as for my wife

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Stir to the door: dare to disturb the match,
And by the

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: My sword: menace Albano fore his own doors.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: No not Albano but Francisco thus, Perfumer, I will make you stink if you stir a; for the rest: well via via

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Iesu, Iesu what intends this? Ha?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O God Sir, you lie as open to my understanding as a Courtesan, I know you as well

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Somebody knows me yet, praise heaven somebody knows me yet.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why look you Sir, I have paid for my knowing of men and women too in my days, I know you are Francisco Soranza the Perfumer, I maugre Seignior Satin I.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Do not tempt my patience, go to, do not.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I know you dwell in Saint Marks lane, at the sign of the Mus cat as well

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Fool, or mad, or drunk no more.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I know where you were dressed, where you were

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Nay then take all, take all, take all

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And I tell not my father, if I make you not loose your office of gutter Master ship; and you be Scavenger next year well: Come Holifernes come good Holifernes come servant.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Francisco Soranza and perfumer and muscat, and gutter master hay, hay, hay, go, go, go, gods f, f, f, 'sfoot; I will to the Duke and I will so ti, ti, ti, tickle them.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Precious, what means he to go out so soon ,
Before the dusk of twilight might deceive
The doubtful priors. What holla.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Whop what devil now?

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: I will feign I know him not, what business fore those doors.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: What is that to thee

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: You come to wrong my friend Sir Lauerdure
Confess or

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: My sword boy, s, s, s, s, soul my sword.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: O my dear rogue thou art a rare dissembler.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: See see.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Francisco did I not help to cloth thee even now
I would have sworn thee Albano my good sweet slave.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: See, see, Iesu, Iesu impostors, cony catchers, Sancta Maria?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Look you, he walks he feigns most excellent.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: Accost him first as if you were ignorant
Of the deceit.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: O dear Albano now thrice happy eyes
To view the hope-less presence of my brother.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Most loved kinsman praise to Heaven yet,
You know Albano but for yonder slaves well.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: Success could not come on more gracious.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Had not you come dear brother Adrian
I think not one would know me. Vlisses dog
Had quicker sense than my dull Countrymen,
Why none had known me.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Doubt you of that? would I might die,
Had I not known the guile I would have sworn
Thou hadst been Albano my nimble cozening knave.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Whip, whip, Heaven preserve all Saint Mark Saint Mark.
Brother Adrian be frantic prithee be
Say I am a Perfumer Francisco hay hay
Is it not some feast day you are all rank drunk
Rats ra, ra, ra, rats knights of the be, be, be, bell, be, be, bell.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: Go go proceed thou dost it rare farewell.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Farewell? ha? is it even so? boy who am I?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: My Lord Albano

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: By this breast you lie
The Samian faith is true, true, I was drowned
And now my soul is skipped into a perfumer a gutter master.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Believe me sir

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: No no I will believe nothing, no,
The disadvantage of all honest hearts
Is quick credulity, perfect state policy
Can cross bite even sense, the worlds turned Juggler,
Casts mists before our eyes Heigh pass re pass
I will credit nothing.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Hence ass.
Doth not Opinion stamp the currant pass,
Of each man's value, virtue, quality?
Had I engrossed the choice commodities
Of heavens traffic, yet reputed vile
I am a rascal; O dear unbelief,
How wealthy dost thou make thy owners wit?
Thou train of knowledge, what a privilege
Thou givest to thy possessor: anchorest him,
From floating with the tide of vulgar faith:
From being damned with multitudes dear unbelief,
I am a Perfumer, I, thinkst thou my blood,
My brothers know not right Albano yet?
Away it is fates, if Albanos name,
Were liable to sense, that I could taste or touch
Or see, or feel it, it might tice belief,
But since it is voice, and air, come to the Muscat boy,
Francisco that is my name it is right, I, I,
What do you lack? what is it you lack right that is my cry.

body.stage: Enter Slip and Noose Trip with the truncheon of a staff torch, and Doit with a Pantofle, Bidet, Holyfernes following. The Cornets sound

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.l: Proclaim our titles

sp.speaker: Doit.
sp.l: Bosphoros Cormelydon Honorificacuminos Bydet.

sp.speaker: Holyf.
sp.l: I think your Majesties a Welshman, you have a horrible long name.

sp.speaker: Bydet.
sp.l: Death or silence proceed.

sp.speaker: Doit.
sp.p: Honorificacuminos Bidet Emperor of Cracks, Prince of Pages, Marquis of Mumchance, and sole regent over a bale of false dice to all his under Ministers health, Crowns, Sack, Tobacco, and stockings uncracked above the shoe.

sp.speaker: Bydet.
sp.p: Ourself will give them their charge, Now let me stroke my beard if I had it, and speak wisely if I knew how: most unconscionable, honest little, or little honest good subjects, inform our person of your several qualities and of the prejudice that is foisted upon you that ourself may purview, prevent, and preoccupy the pustulent dangers incident to all your cases.

sp.speaker: Doit.
sp.l: Here is a petition exhibited of the particular grievances of each sort of pages.

sp.speaker: Bydet.
sp.p: We will vouchsafe in this our public session to peruse them, pleaseth your excellent wagship to be informed that the division of pages is tripartite (tripartite) or three fold, of pages, some be Court pages, others Ordinary gallants pages, and the third apple squires, basket bearers or pages of the placket, with the last we will proceed first, stand forth page of the placket, what is your mistress?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: A kind of puritan.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.l: How live you?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Miserably complaining to your crack ship though we have light Mistresses we are made the Children and servants of darkness, what profane use we are put to, all these gallants more feelingly know then we can lively express, it is to be commiserated and by your royal insight only to be prevented that a male Monkey and the diminutive of a man should be Synonima and no sense. Though we are the dross of your subjects, yet being a kind of page, let us find your Celsitude kind and respective of our time fortunes and births abuse, and so in the name of our whole tribe of empty basket bearers, I kiss your little hands.

sp.speaker: Bidet.
sp.p: Your case is dangerous and almost desperate stand forth ordinary gallants page, what is the nature of your Master?

sp.speaker: Noose.
sp.p: He eats well and right slovenly, and when the dice favour him goes in good clothes, and scours his pink colour silk stockings: when he hath any money he bears his crowns, when he hath none I carry his purse, he cheats well, swears better, but swaggers in a wantons Chamber admirably, he loves his boy and the rump of a crammed Capon, and this summer hath a passing thrifty humour to bottle ale: as contemptuous as Lucifer, as arrogant as ignorance can make him, as libidinous as Priapus, he keeps me as his adamant to draw metal after to his lodging, I curl his periwig, paint his cheeks, perfume his breath, I am his froterer or rubber in a Hot house, the prop of his lies, the bearer of his falls dice, and yet for all this like the Persian Louse that eats biting, and biting eats, so I say sithing and sithing say my end is to paste up a Si quis my Masters fortunes are forced to cashier me and so six to one I fall to be a Pippin squire. Hic finis priami this is the end of pick pockets.

sp.speaker: Bydet.
sp.l: Stand forth Court page, thou lookest pale and wan.

sp.speaker: Trip.
sp.l: Most ridiculous Emperor.

sp.speaker: Bydet.
sp.l: O say no more, I know thy miseries, what betwixt thy Lady, her Gentlewoman and thy Masters late gaming thou mayst look pale. I know thy miseries and I condole thy calamities, thou art borne well, bred ill but diest worst of all, thy blood most commonly gentle, thy youth ordinarily idle, and thy age too often miserable. When thy first suit is fresh, thy cheeks clear of Court soils, and thy Lord fallen out with his Lady, so long may be he will chuck thee under the chin, call thee good pretty ape and give thee a scrap from his own trencher, but after he never beholds thee, but when thou squirest him with a torch to a wantons sheets, or lights his Tobacco pipe. never useth thee but as his pander never, regardeth thee but as an idle bur that stickest upon the nap of his fortune, and so naked thou camest into the world and naked thou must return; whom serve you.

sp.speaker: Holy.
sp.l: A fool.

sp.speaker: Bydet.
sp.p: Thou art my happiest subject, the service of a fool is the only blessedest slavery that ever put on a chain and a blew cote, they know not what nor for what they give, but so they give it is good, so it be good they give : fortunes are ordained for fools, as fools are for fortune, to play with all not to use, hath he taken an oath of allegiance is he of our brotherhood yet?

sp.speaker: Holy.
sp.p: Not yet right venerable Honorificac cac cac cacuminos Bidet but as little an infant as I am I will, and with the grace of wit I will deserve it.

sp.speaker: Bydet.
sp.p: You must perform a valorous Virtuous and religious exploit first in desert of your order.

sp.speaker: Holyf.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: Cozen thy master, he is a fool, and was created for men of wit such as thyself to make use of.

sp.speaker: Holy.
sp.p: Such as myself. Nay faith for wit I think for my age or so, but on, sir.

sp.speaker: Bidet.
sp.p: That thou mayst the easier purge him of superfluous blood I will describe thy Masters constitution, he loves and is beloved of himself and one more; his dog. There is a company of unbraced untrussed, rutters in the town, that crinkle in the hams swearing their flesh is their only living, and when they have any crowns, cry god a mercy Moll and shrugging let the Cuckolds pay for it: intimating that their maintenance flows from the wantonness of Merchants wives, when in troth the plain troth is, the plain and the stand, or the plain stand and deliver, delivers them all their living. These comrades have persuaded thy Master that there is no way to redeem his peach colour satin suit from pawn but by the love of a Citizens wife, he believes it, they flout him he feeds them, and now it is our honest and religious meditation that he feed us. Holyfernes Puppi.

sp.speaker: Holy.
sp.l: Pippo and shall please you.

sp.speaker: Bydet.
sp.p: Pippo it is our will and pleasure thou suit thyself like a Merchants wife, leave the managing of the sequence unto our prudence.

sp.speaker: Holy.
Bydet.
sp.p: Our majesty dismounteth, and we put off our greatness, and now my little knaves I am plain Crack as I am Bosphoros Carmelidon Honorificacuminos Bydet I am imperious: honour sparkles in mine eyes; but as I am Crack I will convey crossbite and cheat upon Simplicius I will feed, satiate and fill your paunches: replenish, stuff or furnish your purses, we will laugh when others weep, sing when others sith, feed when others starve, and be drunk when others are sober, this my charge at the loose, as you love our brother hood, avoid true speech square dice, small liquor, and above all, those too ungentleman-like protestations of indeed and verily, and so gentle Appollo touch thy nimble string our scene is done yet fore we cease we sing.

body.stage: Enter Celia Meletza Lyzabetta and Lucea

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: Faith sister I long to play with a feather, prithee Lucia bring the shuttle cock.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: Out on him light pated Fantastic, he is like one of our gallants at.

sp.speaker: Lyza.
sp.l: I wonder who thou speakest well of?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Why of myself, for by my troth I know none else will.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Sweet sister Meletza let us sit in judgment a little, faith of my servant Monsieur Lauerdure

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Troth well for a servant, but for a husband (sigh) I.

sp.speaker: Lyza.
sp.l: Why why?

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: Why he is not a plain fool, nor fair, nor fat, nor rich, rich fool. But he is a knight, his honour will give the passado in the presence tomorrow night, I hope he will deserve: all I can say is as, as the common fiddlers will say in their God send you well to do.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: How thinkst thou of the amorous Iacomo

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: Iacomo why on my bare troth.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: Why bare troth.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: Because my troth is like his chin it hath no hair on it ; gods me his face looks like the head of a tabor, but trust me he hath a good wit.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Who told you so.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: One that knows, one that can tell?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: Who is that.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: Himself.

sp.speaker: Lyz.
sp.p: Well wench, thou hadst a servant one Fabius what hast thou done with him.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: I done with him? out of him puppy, by this feather his beard is directly brick colour, and perfectly fashioned like the husk of a chestnut, he kisses with the driest lip; fie on him.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: O but your servant Quadratus the absolute Courtier.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: Fie, fie, speak no more of him, he lives by begging?
He is a fine Courtier flatters admirable, kisses
Fair Madam, smells surpassing sweet, wears
And holds up the arras, supports the tapestry,
When I pass into the presence very gracefully and
I assure you.

sp.speaker: Lucea.
sp.l: Madam here is your shuttle cock

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: Sister is not your waiting wench rich?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: Why sister why?

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: Because she can flatter: prithee call her not,
She has 24. hours to Madam yet; come you
Yon prate i'faith I will toss you from post to pillar.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: You post and I pillar.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: No, no, you are the only post, you must support, prove a wench and bear, or else all the building of your delight will fall ~~

sp.speaker: Celia
sp.l: Down.

sp.speaker: Lyza.
sp.l: What must I stand out?

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: Aye by my faith till you be married.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Why do you toss then?

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: Why I am wed wench.

sp.speaker: Celea
sp.l: prithee to whom.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: To the true husband right head of a woman, my will , which vows never to marry till I mean to be a fool, a slave, starch cambric ruffs, and make candles (purr) it is down serve again good wench.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: By your pleasing cheek you play well.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: Nay good creature prithee do not flatter me, I thought it was for something you go cased in your velvet scabbard, I warrant these laces were never stitched on with true stitch, I have a plain waiting wench she speaks plain, and faith, she goes plain, she is virtuous and because she should go like virtue by the consent of my bounty she shall never have above two smocks to her back, for that is the fortune of desert, and the maine in fashion or reward of merit (purr) just thus do I use my servants, I strive to catch them in my racket, and no sooner caught but I toss them away, if he fly well and have good feathers I play with them till he be down, and then my maid serves him to me again, if a slug and weak winged if he be down there let him lie.

sp.speaker: Celea.
sp.l: Good Mell I wonder how many servants thou hast.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: Troth so do I, let me see Dupatzo

sp.speaker: Lyxa.
sp.l: Dupatzo which Dupatzo.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: Dupatzo the elder brother the fool, he that bought the half penny riband wearing it in his ear swearing it was the duchess of Millans favour, he into whose head a man may travel 10, leagues before he can meet with his eyes, then there is my chub my Epicure. Quadratus that rubs his guts, claps his paunch and cries Riuo entertaining my ears perpetually with a most strong discourse of the praise of bottle ale and red Herrings, then there is Simplicius Faber

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Why he is a fool.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: True or else he would never be my servant, then there is the cap cloaked Courtier Baltazar he wears a double treble quadruple ruff, Aye in the summer time, faith I have servants Enough and I doubt not but by my ordinary pride and extraordinary cunning to get more. Monsieur Lauerdure with a troupe of gallants is entering.

sp.speaker: Lyza.
sp.l: He capers the lascivious blood about.
Within heart pants, nor leaps the eye nor lips:
Prepare yourselves to kiss for you must be kissed.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: By my troth it is a pretty thing to be towards marriage, a pretty loving: look where he comes ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lauer.
sp.l: Good day sweet love.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Wish her good night man.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: God morrow sister.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: A curtsy to you caper, tomorrow morn I will call you brother.

sp.speaker: Lauer.
sp.l: But much much falls betwixt the cup and lip.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Be not too confident the knot may slip.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Bounty, blessedness, and the spirit of wine attend my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Thanks good chub.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: God ye god morrow heartily mistress, and how do you since last I saw you.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Gods me you must not inquire how she does, that is privy counsel, fie, there is manners indeed.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Pray you pardon my incivility, I was somewhat bold with you, but believe me I will never be so saucy to ask you how you do again, as long as I live la.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Square chub, what sullen black is that.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: A tassel that hangs at my purse strings, he dogs me and I give him scraps and pay for his ordinary, feed him, he liquors himself in the juice of my bounty, and when he hath sucked up strength of spirit he squeezeth it in my own face, when I have refined and sharped his wits with good food, he cuts my fingers, and breaks jests upon me, I bear them, and beat him: but by this light the dull eyed thinks he does well, does very well, and but that he and I are of two faiths I fill my belly, and feeds his brain, I could find in my heart to hug him, to hug him.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: prithee persuade him to assume spirit and salute us .

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: Lampatho, Lampatho art out of countenance, for wits sake salute these beauties, how dost like them?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, I can liken them to nothing, but great men's great horse upon great days, whose tails are trust up in silk and silver.
