sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.l: To them man, salute them.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Bless you fair Ladies, God make you all his servants.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: God make you all his servants.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: He is holpen well had need of you, for be it spoken without profanism he hath more in this train, I fear me you have more servants than he, I am sure the Devil is an Angel of darkness.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: Aye but those are Angels of light.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Light Angels, prithee leave them, with draw a little and hear a Sonnet prithee, hear a Sonnet.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: Made of Albanos widow that was, and Monsieur Lauerdures wife that must be.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Come leave his lips and command some liquor, if you have no Bottle Ale, command some Claret wine and Bourrage, for that is my predominate humour sleek billed Bacchus let us fill thy guts.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: Nay hear it, and relish it judiciously.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: I do relish it most judicially.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: Adored excellence, delicious sweet.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Delicious sweet good, very good.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: If thou canst taste the purer juice of love.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: If thou canst taste the purer juice, good still, good still.
I do relish it, it tastes sweet.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: Is not the metaphor good, is it not well followed?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Passing good, very pleasing.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: Is it not sweet.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Let me see it I will make it sweet,
I will soak it in the juice of Helicon
By'r'Lady, passing sweet, good, passing sweet.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: You wrong my Muse.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: The Irish flux upon thy Muse, thy whorish Muse,
Here is no place for her loose brothelry,
We will not deal with her, go, away, away,

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: I will be revenged.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: How prithee in a play? come, come, be sociable
In private severance from society,
Here leaps a vain of blood inflamed with love,
Mounting to pleasure, all addict to mirth,
Thou wilt read a Satire or a Sonnet now,
Clagging their airy humour with

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Lamp oil, watch Candles, Rug gowns and small juice,
Thin commons, four a clock rising, I renounce you all,
Now may I eternally abandon meat
Rust fusty you which most embraced disuse,
You a made me an Ass, thus shaped my lot,
I am a mere Scholar, that is a mere sot.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Come then Lamp, I will pour fresh Oil into thee,
Apply thy spirit that it may nimbly turn,
Unto the habit, fashion of the age,
I will make thee man the Scholar, enable thy behaviour,
Apt for the entertain of any presence:
I will turn thee gallant, first thou shalt have a Mistress,
How is thy spirit raised to yonder beauty?
She with the sanguine cheek, the dimpled chin,
The pretty amorous smile that clips her lips,
And dallies bought her cheek
She with the speaking eye,
That casts out beams as ardent as those flakes,
Which singed the world by rash brained Phaeton
She with the lip, O lips she for whose sake,
A man could find in his heart to in-hell himself,
There is more Philosophy, more theorems,
More demonstrations, all invincible,
More clear divinity drawn on her cheek,
Than in all volumes tedious paraphrase,
Of musty old, O who would staggering doubt,
The souls eternity, seeing it hath
Of heavenly beauty, but to case it up,
Who would distrust a supreme existence,
Able to confound when it can creale,
Such heaven on earth able to entrance,
Amaze: O Aye it is providence, not chance.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now by the front of Jove methinks her eye
Shoots more spirit in me, O beauty feminine
How powerful art thou, what deep magic lies
Within the circle of thy speaking eyes.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Why now could I eat thee, thou dost please mine appetite, I can desist thee, God made thee a good fool, and happy and ignorant, and amorous, and rich and frail, and a Satirist, and an Essayist and sleepy, and proud, and indeed a fool and then thou shalt be sure of all these. Do but scorn her she is thine own, accost her carelessly, and her eye promiseth she will be bound to the good abearing.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Now sister Meletza dost mark their crest, some straggling thoughts transport thy attentiveness from his discourse, was it Iacomos or our brothers plot?

sp.speaker: Lauer.
sp.p: Both, both, sweet Lady, my Page heard all, we met the rogue, so like Albano I beat the rogue.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Aye but when you were gone the rogue beat me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Now take my counsel, listen.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: A pretty youth, a pretty well shaped youth, a good leg, a very good eye, a sweet ingenious face, and I warrant a good wit, nay which is more, if he be poor I assure my soul he is chaste and honest, good faith I fancy, I fancy him, I and I may chance, well I will think the rest.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: I say be careless still, court her without complement take spirit.

sp.speaker: Lauer.
sp.l: Wert not a pleasing jest for me to cloth
Another rascal like Albano say
And rumour him returned without all deceit,
Would not beget errors most ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Meletza bella belletza, Madonna, bella bella genteletza prithee kiss this initiated gallant.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: How would it please you I should respect ye.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: As anything , What you will as nothing.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: As nothing, how will you value my love.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Why just as you respect me, as nothing, for out of nothing, nothing is bred, so nothing shall not beget anything, anything bring nothing, nothing bring anything, anything and nothing shall be What you will my speech mounting to the value of myself which is.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: What sweet

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Your nothing light as yourself senseless as your sex, and just as you would have me, nothing.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: Your wit skips a morisco, but by the brightest spangle of my tier, I vouchsafe you entire unaffected favour, were this gentle spirit be not proud. Believe it youth slow speech, swift love doth often shroud.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: My soul is entranced your favour doth transport,
My sense past sense, by your adored graces,
I dote, am rapt.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: Nay if you fall to passion and past sense,
My Breast is no harbour for your love, go pack, hence.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: 'Sfoot thou gull, thou inky scholar, ha, thou whoreson fop,
Wilt not thou clap into our fashioned gallantry,
Couldst not be proud and scornful, aloof and vain
Gods my hearts object, what a plague is this:
My soul is entranced, 'sfoot couldst not clip and kiss,
My soul is entranced, ten thousand crowns at least
Lost lost, my soul is entranced, loves life O beast

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Celia open, open Celia I would enter, open Celia

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Celia open, open Celia I would enter open Celia

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: What Celia let in thy husband Albano what Celia

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What Celia let in thy husband Albano what Celia

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: f, f, f, 'Sfoot let Albano enter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: f, f, f, 'Sfoot let Albano enter.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: Sweet breast you have played the wag i'faith.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Believe it sweet not I.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: Come you have attired some fiddler like Albano to fright the perfumer, there is the jest.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Good fortunes to our sister.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: And a speedy marriage.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: Then we must wish her no good fortunes.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: For shame, for shame straight clear your house; sweep out this dust, fling out this trash, return to modesty your husband I say your husband Albano that was supposed drowned is returned Aye and at the door.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: Ha, ha my husband, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: Laugh you, shameless? laugh you?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Come, come, your Plot is discovered, good faith kinsmen I am no scold: to shape a Perfumer like my husband, O sweet jest.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Last hopes all known.

sp.speaker: Celi.
sp.p: For penance of your fault will you maintain a jest now, my love hath tired some fiddler like Albano like the Perfumer.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Not I by blessedness not I.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Come it is true, do but support the jest and you shall surfeit, with laughter.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Faith we condescend it will not be crossed I see,
Marriage and hanging go by destiny.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: B, b, b, bar out Albano O Adulterous impudent.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: B, b, b, bar out Albano O thou matchless g, g, g, giglet.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Let them in, let them in, now, now, now observe, observe, look, look, look.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: That sames a fiddler, shaped like thee, fear nought, be confident thou shalt know the jest hereafter, be confident; fear nought, blush not, stand firm.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Now brothers, now gallants, now sisters now call a Perfumer a gutter master, bar me my house, beat me: baffle me, scoff me, deride me, ha that I were a young man again, by the mass I would have you all by the ears, by the mass law; I am Francisco Soranza am I not giglet: strumpet, cutters, swaggerers, brothel haunters, I am Francisco O god, O slaves, O dogs, dogs, curs.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: No sir pray you pardon us, we confess you are not Francisco nor a Perfumer, but even.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: But even Albano

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: But even a fiddler, a miniken tickler, a pum, pum.

sp.speaker: Frau.
sp.l: A scraper, scraper.
Art not ashamed before Albanos face,
To clip his spouse, O shameless impudent

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Well said perfumer.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: A fiddler a scraper, a miniken tickler, a pum, a pum, even now a Perfumer, now a fiddler, I will be even What you will do, do do, k, k, k, kiss my wife be, be, be, be, fore.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Why wouldst have him kiss her behind?

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Before my own f, f, f, face.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Well done fiddler.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: I will f, f, fiddle ye.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Dost f, f, flout me.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Dost m, m, m, mock me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I will to the Duke I will p, p, p, paste up infamies on every post.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: It was rarely, rarely done, away, away.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: I will f, f, follow, though I st, st, st, stut, I will stumble to the Duke in p, p, plain language, I pray you use my wife well, good faith she was a kind soul and an honest woman once, I was her husband and was called Albano before I was drowned, but now after my resurrection I an I know not what indeed brothers, and indeed sisters and in deed wife I am: What you will dost thou laugh, dost thou ge, ge, ge, girn; a p, p, p, perfumer a fiddler, a Diabalo, matre the Dios I will f, f, f, firk you by the Lord now, now I will.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Ha ha it is a good rogue, a good rogue.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: A good rogue ha, I know him not.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: No good sweet love come come dissemble not,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Nay if you dread nothing happy be my lot
Come Via sest come fair cheeks, come let us dance,
The sweets of love is amorous dalliance.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: All friends, all happy friends, my veins are light,

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Thy prayers are now god send it quickly night.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: And then come morning.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: I that is the hopeful day,

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Aye there thou hittest it.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Pray God he hit it.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Play.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: They say there is revels and a Play at Court.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: A Play tonight ?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Aye it is this gallants wit,

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Is it good is it good?

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: I fear it will hardly hit.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: I like thy fear, well, it will have better chance,
there is nought more hateful than rank ignorance.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: Come gallants the table spread will you to dinner?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Yes first a maine at dice and then we will eat.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Truly the best wits have the baddest fortune at dice still.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Who will Play, who will play.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Not I, in truth I have still exceeding bad fortune at dice.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: Come shall we in, i'faith thou art sudden sad,
Dost fear the shadow of my long dead Lord.

sp.speaker: Lauer,
sp.l: Shadow ha, I cannot tell
Time trieth all things well. well, well.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Would I were time then, I thought it was for something that the old fornicator was bald behind; go pass on pass on.

body.stage: The Curtains are drawn by a Page, and Celia and Lauerdure, Quadratus and Lyzabetta, Lampatho and Meletza Simplicius and Lucea displayed sitting at Dinner. The Song is sung, during which a Page whispers with Simplicius

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Feed and be fat my fair Calipolis
Riuo here is good juice, fresh Burrage boy?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I commend, commend myself to ye Lady.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: In troth Sir you dwell far from neighbours that are enforced to commend yourself.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Why Simplicius whether now man, for good fashions sake stir not, fit still, sit still.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I must needs rise, much good do it you.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Dost thou think thy rising will do them much good, sit still, sit still, carve me of that good Melletza fill Bacchus fill.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I must needs be gone, and you will come to my Chamber tomorrow morning, I will send you a hundred crowns.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: In the name of Prosperity, what tide of happiness so suddenly is flood upon thee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I will keep a horse and four boys with grace of fortune now.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Now then i'faith get up and ride.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And I do not? I will thwack a Jerkin till he groan again with Gold lace: let me see, what should I desire of God, marry a Cloak lined with rich Taffeta, white Satin suit, and my gilt Rapier from pawn, nay she shall give me a Chain of Pearl that shall pay for all, good boy, good Seignior good boy, good Seignior

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Why now, thou speaketh in the most embraced fashion that our time hugs, no sooner a good fortune, or a fresh suit falls upon a fellow that would have been gulled to have shoved into your society, but and he met you he fronts you with a faint eye, throws a squint glance over a wried shoulder and cries twixt the teeth, as very parsimonious of breath, good boy, good Seignior, good boy, good Seignior death: I will search the life blood of your hopes.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And a fresh Pearl colour silk stocking o IIII, I will go to the half crown ordinary every meal, I will have my Ivory box of Tobacco, I will converse with none but Counts and Courtiers now good boy, good Seignior, a pair of massy silver Spurs, to a hatch short sword, and then your embroidered hanger, and good Seignior.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Shut the windows, darken the room, fetch whips, the fellow is mad, he raves, he raves, talks idly, lunatic, who procures thy ~~

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: One that has eat fat Capon, sucked the boiled Chicken, and let out his wit with the fool of bounty, one Fabius I will scorn him, he goes upon Fridays in black satin.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Fabius by this light, a cogging Clietor, he lives on love of Merchants wives, he stands on the base, of mains, he furnisheth your ordinary, for which he feeds scot free, keeps fair gold in his purse, to put on upon mains, by which he lives and keeps a fair boy at his heels, he is damned Fabius

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: He is a fine man law, and has a good wit for when he list he can go in black Satin, Aye and in a cloak lined with unshorn Velvet.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: By the salvation of humanity he is more pestilent than the plague of Lice that fell upon Egypt thou hast been knave if thou credit it, thou art an Ass if thou follow it, and shalt be a perpetual Idiot if thou pursue it, renounce the world, the flesh, the Devil, and thy trust in men's wives for they will double with thee, and so I betake myself to the sucking of the juice Capon, my ingle Bottle ale, and his Gentleman usher that squires him red herring, a fool I found thee and a fool I leave thee, bear record heave it is against the providence of my speech, God boy good Seignior.

body.stage: Enter Slip Nows, Doit and Bydet

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, God boy good Seignior, what a fool it is, ha, ha, what an Ass it is, save you young Gentlemen, is she coming, will she meet me, shall us encounter ha?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: You were not lapped in your Mothers smock, you have not a good cheek, an enticing eye, a smooth skin, a well shaped leg, a fair hand, you cannot bring a wench into a fools paradise for you?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Not I by this garter, I am a fool, a very Ninny I, how call you her? how call you her?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: Call her, you rise on your right side today marry, call her, her name is Mistress Perpetuana she is not a very fair, nor goes extraordinary gay.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: She has a good skin?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: A good skin? she is wealthy, her husbands is a fool, she will make you, she wears the breeches: she will make you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I will keep two men and they shall be Taylors, they shall make suits continually, and those shall be cloth of silver.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: You may go in beaten precious Stones every day, marry I must acquaint you with some observances which you must pursue most religiously, she has a fool, a natural fool waits on her, that is indeed her pander to him, at the first you must be bounteous, what so ere he craves, be it your Hat, Cloak, Rapier, Purse, or such trifle, give it, give it , the night will pay all: and to draw all suspect, from pursuing her love for base gain sake.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Give it by this light, I will give it , wert, gain, I care not for her Chain of Pearl, only her love; gain? the first thing her bounty shall fetch is my blush colour Satin suit from pawn: gain?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: When you hear one wind a Cornet, she is coming down Saint Marks street, prepare your speech, suck your lips, lighten your spirits, fresh your blood, sleek your cheeks, for now thou shalt be made forever (a perpetual and eternal gull)

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I shall so ravish her with my court ship, I have such variety of discourse, such copy of phrase to begin, as this; sweet Lady Vlisses Dog after his Masters ten years travel, I shall so tickle her, or thus, Pure beauty there is a stone.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Two stones man.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Called, it is no matter what; I have the eloquence, I am not to seek I warrant you.
sp.stage: The Cornet is winded, Enter Pippo Bydet, Pippo attired like a Merchants wife, and Bydet like a Fool
sp.l: Sweet Lady Vlisses dog, there is a stone called ~~ O Lord what shall I say.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Is all your eloquence come to this?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: The glorious radiant of your glimmering eyes, your glittering beauties blind my wit, and dazzled my ~~

sp.speaker: Pippo.
sp.l: I will put on my mask and please you, pray you wink, pray you.

sp.speaker: Bidet.
sp.p: O fine man, my mistress loves you best, I dreamt you game this sword and dagger, I love your Hat and Feather, O.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Do not cry man, do not cry man, thou shalt have them Aye and they were

sp.speaker: Bydet.
sp.p: O that purse with all the white pence in it, fine man I love you, give you the fine red pence soon at night, he, I thank you where is the fool now?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: He has all my money, I have to keep myself, and

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Poght.

sp.speaker: Pippo.
sp.p: Sir the fool shall lead you to my house, the fool shall not, at night I expect you, till then take this seal of my affection.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: What Simplicius

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Aye come Quadratus Gentlemen as yet I can but thank you, but I must be trusted for my ordinary soon at night, or stay I will the fool has unfurnished me, but it will come again, good boy.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: What ho Simplicius

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Good boy, good boys, I come, I come, good boys, good boys.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: The fool shall weight on thee, Now do I merit to be yclipped Bosphoros Carmelydon Honorificacuminos Bydett who who has any square Dice?

sp.speaker: Pippo.
sp.l: Marry Sir that have I.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.l: Thou shalt loose thy share for it in our purchase.

sp.speaker: Pippo.
sp.l: I pray you now, pray you now.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.l: Sooner the whistle of a Mariner,
Shall sleek the rough curbs of the Ocean back,
sp.p: Now speak I like myself thou shalt loose thy share.

body.stage: Enter Quadratus, Lauerdure and Celia, Simplicius Meletza, Lyzabetta Lucea and Lampatho

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Ha take all then, ha.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Without cloak or hat or rapier fie,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Gods me, look yonder, who gave you these things?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.l: Mistress Perpetuanos fool.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Mistress Perpetuanos fool, ha, ha , there lies a jest, Seignior the fool promised me he would not leave me.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: I know the fool well, he will stick to you, does not use to forsake any youth that is enamoured on an other man's wife, he strives to keep company with a crimson satin suit continually, he loves to be alone with a Critique, a good wit self conceited, a hawk bearer, a dog keeper, and great with the nobility, he dotes upon a mere scholar an honest flat fool, but above all he is all one with a fellow whose cloak hath a better inside than his out side, and his body richer lined than his brain.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Godso I am cozened.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Pray you master pardon me, I must loose my share.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Give me my purse again.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: You gave it me and I will keep it.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Well done my honest crack thou shalt be my ingle for it.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: He shall keep all maugre thy beardless chin thy eyes.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I may go starve till Midsummer quarter.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Fool get thee hence,

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: I will to school again that I will, I left in Ass in presenti and I will begin in Ass in presenti and so good night fair gentry.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: The triple Idiots coxcomb crowns thee,
Bitter epigrams confound thee.
Cuckold be when ere thou bride thee,
Through every comic scene be drawn,
Never come thy clothes from pawn.
Never may thy shame be sheathed,
Never kiss a wench sweet breathed.

body.stage: Enter as many Pages with Torches as you can, Randolfo and Adrian, Iacomo bare, the Duke with attendants.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Cease the Duke approacheth it is almost night,
For the Dukes up, now begins his day
Come grace his entrance; lights lights now gins our play.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Still these same bawling pipes, sound softer strains
Slumber our sense, tut these are vulgar strains,
Cannot your trembling wires throw a chain
Of powerful rapture bout our mazed sense
Why is our chair thus cushioned tapestry
Why is our bed tired with wanton sports?
Why are we clothed in glistering attires,
If common bloods can hear, can, feel,
Can sit as soft, lie as lascivious
Stut all as rich as the greatest Potentate,
Soul, and you cannot feast my thirsting ears
With aught but what the lip of common berth can taste,
Take all away your labours idly waste
What sport for night.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A Comedy, entitled Temperance

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: What sot elects that subject for the Court,
What should dame Temperance do here, away,
The itch on Temperance your moral play.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Duke, Prince, royal blood, thou that hast the best means to be damned of any Lord in Veince thou great man, let me kiss thy flesh, I am fat and therefore faithful, I will do that which few of thy subjects do; love thee, but I will never do, that which all thy subjects do; flatter thee, thy humours real, good, a Comedy?
sp.l: No and thy sense would banquet in delights,
Appropriate to the blood of Emperors;
Peculiar to the state of Majesty,
That none can relish but dilated greatness.
Vouchsafe to view the structure of a scene
That stands on tragic solid passion,
O that is fit traffic to commerce with births:
Strained from the mud of base humble brains,
Give them a scene may force their struggling blood
Rise up on tiptoe in attention,
And fill their intellect with pure elixed wit,
O that is for greatness apt, for Princes fit.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Darest thou then undertake to suit our ears,
With such rich vestment.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Dare; yes my Prince I dare, nay more, I will,
And I will present a subject worth thy soul:
The honoured end of Cato Vtican

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Who will personate him.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Marry that will I on sudden without change.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Thou wantest a beard.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Tush a beard never made Cato though many men's Cato hang only on their chin.
Suppose this flower the City vtica
The time the night that prolonged Catos death:
Now being placed among his Philosophers,
These first discourse the souls eternity.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: Cato grants that I am sure, for he was valiant, and honest, which an Epicure never was, and a coward never will be.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Then Cato holds a distinct notion,
Of individual actions after death:
This being argued his resolve maintains,
A true magnanimous spirit should give up dirt
To dirt, and with his own flesh dead his flesh,
Fore chance should force it crouch unto his foe:
To kill ones-self some I, some hold it no,
O these are points would entice away ones soul:
To breaks indenture of base prenticeage,
And run away from his body in swift thoughts
To melt in contemplation luscious sweets,
Now my voluptuous Duke I will feed thy sense,
Worth his creation: give me audience.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My liege my royal liege, hear, hear my suit.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Now may thy breath never smell sweet as long as thy lungs can pant for breaking my speech, thou Muscouite, thou stinking perfumer.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is not this Albano our some times Courtier?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No troth but Francisco your always perfumer.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Lorenzo Celso our brave Venice Duke Albano Belletzo thy Merchant, thy soldier, thy Courtier, thy slave, thy anything , thy What thou wilt kisseth thy noble blood, do me right or else I am canonised a cuckold, canonised a cuckold, I am abused, I am abused, my wife is abused, my clothes abused, my shape, my house my all abused, I am sworn out of myself, beated out of myself baffled, jeered at, laughed at, bard my own house, debarred my own wife, whilst others swill my wines, gourmandize my meat, meat, kiss my wife, O gods, O gods, O gods, O gods, O gods.

sp.speaker: Lauer.
sp.l: Who is it? who is it?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: Come sweet this is your waggery i'faith, as if you knew him not.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes I fear I do too well, would I could slide away invisible.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Assured this is he.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: My worthy liege the jest comes only thus.
Now to stop and cross it with mere like deceit:
All being known the French knight hath disguised,
A fiddler like Albano too, to fright the perfumer, this is all.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Art sure it is true.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: it is confessed it is right.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Aye it is right, it is true, right, I am a fiddler, a fiddler, a fiddler 'sfoot a fiddler; I will not believe thee thou art a woman, and it is known veritas non querit angulos truth seeks not to lurk under farthingales, veritas non querit angulos a fiddler?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Worthy sir pardon, and permit me first to confess yourself, your deputation dead hath made my love live, to offend you.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Aye , mock on, scoff on, flout on, do do do.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Troth sir in serious.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Aye good, good, come hither Celia
Burst breast, rive heart a sunder? Celia
Why startest thou back: seest thou this Celia
O me how often with lascivious touch thy lip,
Hath kissed this mark? how oft this much wronged breast
Hath borne the gentle weight of thy soft cheek?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: O me my dearest Lord, my sweet, sweet love.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: What a fiddler, a fiddler? now thy love.
I am sure thou scornest; it nay Celia I could tell
What on the night before I went to sea,
And took my leave with Hymeneal rights
What, thou lispsed
Into my ear, a fiddler and perfumer now.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: And

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Dear brother.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Most respected Seignior
Believe it by the sacred end of love,
What much, much wrong hath forced your patience
Proceeded from most dear affied love ,
Devoted to your house.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: Believe it brother.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: Nay yourself when you shall hear the occurrences will say it is happy, comical.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Assure thee brother.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Shall I be brave, shall I be myself now, love, give me thy love, brothers give me your breasts, French knight reach me thy hand, perfumer thy fist. Duke I invite thee, love I forgive thee: Frenchman I hug thee, I will know all, I will pardon all, and I will laugh at all.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: And I will curse you all.
O ye have interrupt a scene.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Quadratus we will hear these points discussed,
With apter and more calm affected hours.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Well, good, good.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Wast even so i'faith why then capricious mirth,
Skip light moriscoes in our frolic blood,
Flagged veins, sweet, plump with fresh infused joys:
Laughter pucker our cheeks, make shoulders shog,
With chucking lightness, love once more thy lips,
Forever clasp our hands, our hearts, our Crests,
Thus front, thus eyes, thus cheek, thus all shall meet.
Shall clip, shall hug, shall kiss, my dear, dear sweet,
Duke wilt thou see me revel, come love dance,
Court gallants court; suck amorous dalliance.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Beauty your heart.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: First sir accept my hands.
She leaps too rash, that falls in sudden bands.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Shall I despair? never will I love more.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: No sea so boundless vast but hath a shore.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Why marry me.
Thou canst have but soft flesh, good blood, sound bones.
And that which fills up all your bracks, good stones.

sp.speaker: Lyzabet.
sp.l: Stones, Trees and beasts in love still firmer prove,
Than man, I will none no hold fasts in your loves.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Since not the Mistress, come on Faith the maid.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: Ten thousand Ducats too to boot are laid.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Why then wind Cornets, lead on jolly lad.

sp.speaker: Alla.
sp.l: Excuse me gallants though my legs lead wrong.
It is my first footing, wind out nimble tongue.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It is well, it is well, how shall we spend this night?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Gulp Rhenish Wine my liege, let our paunch rent,
Suck merry Jellies, preview but not prevent
No mortal can the miseries of life.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: I home invite you all, come sweet, sweet wife,
My liege vouchsafe thy presence, drink till the ground look blew, boy.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Live still springing hopes, still in fresh new joys,
May your loves happy hit in fair cheeked wives,
Your flesh still plump with sapped restoratives,
That is all my honest frolic heart can wish,
A Fico for the mew and Envious pish,
Till night, I wish good food, and pleasing day,
But then sound rest, so ends or slight writ play.
